generalfeedback.text:
Worked Solution

Two vectors are considered equivalent (or identical) if they have the same magnitude (length) and the same direction. In terms of coordinates, this means their horizontal and vertical components must be equal.

Step 1: Determine the components of the fixed vector \(\vec{p_1p_2}\).

We calculate the change in \(x\) and the change in \(y\) from point \(p_1\) to \(p_2\):

  • Change in \(x\) (\(\Delta x\)): \( {@p2x@} - ({@p1x@}) = {@v1[1]@} \)
  • Change in \(y\) (\(\Delta y\)): \( {@p2y@} - ({@p1y@}) = {@v1[2]@} \)

So, the vector \(\vec{p_1p_2}\) can be written as the column vector \(\mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} {@v1[1]@} \\ {@v1[2]@} \end{pmatrix}\).

Step 2: Adjust \(\vec{p_3p_4}\).

For \(\vec{p_3p_4}\) to be identical to \(\vec{p_1p_2}\), it must have these same components. You can place the start point \(p_3\) anywhere on the grid, but the end point \(p_4\) must be positioned relative to \(p_3\) such that:

  • \(x_4 = x_3 + {@v1[1]@}\)
  • \(y_4 = y_3 + {@v1[2]@}\)

The image below shows one correct solution. The blue vector is the target \(\vec{p_1p_2}\), and the green vector is \(\vec{p_3p_4}\) correctly placed to be equivalent.

[[jsxgraph width="500px" height="500px"]] JXG.Options.text.useMathJax = true; var board = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard(divid, { boundingbox : [-5.5, 5.5, 5.5, -5.5], axis : true, showNavigation:false, showCopyright:false}); // The target fixed vector (Blue) var p1 = board.create('point', {#p1#}, { name : 'p_1', fixed: true, size:3, color:'#0000ff' }); var p2 = board.create('point', {#p2#}, { name : 'p_2', fixed: true, size:3, color:'#0000ff' }); board.create('arrow', [p1, p2], { fixed : true, strokeWidth : 4, strokeOpacity : .6, color:'#0000ff' }); // The solution vector (Green) - Fixed in a correct position // We place p3 at its randomized initial starting point defined in variables var p3_sol = board.create('point', {#p3#}, { name : 'p_3', fixed: true, size:3, color:'#009900' }); // We calculate the correct p4 position relative to p3 using the vector component v1 var p4x_sol = {#p3x#} + {#v1[1]#}; var p4y_sol = {#p3y#} + {#v1[2]#}; var p4_sol = board.create('point', [p4x_sol, p4y_sol], { name : 'p_4', fixed: true, size:3, color:'#009900' }); board.create('arrow', [p3_sol, p4_sol], { fixed : true, strokeWidth : 4, strokeOpacity : .8, color:'#009900' }); [[/jsxgraph]]

Graphically, the arrow for \(\vec{p_3p_4}\) must look parallel to \(\vec{p_1p_2}\), point in the same direction, and have the same length.

Daniel Murunga

Interactive JSXGraph task: Given a fixed vector p1p2 defined by random coordinates, the student must manipulate points p3 and p4 to create an equivalent vector p3p4. Tests understanding of vector components and equivalence (magnitude/direction) independent of position.
